The curr_chunk is: "SECTION 1. DISABILITY MOBILITY ADVISORY COUNCIL."

The summarized chunk is: "Disability Mobility Advisory Council." Establishment of a Disability Mobility Advisory Council within the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, with diverse membership appointed by the Secretary of Transportation for three-year terms. The Disability Mobility Advisory Council, established within the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, consists of members appointed by the Secretary of Transportation for three-year terms. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and the Council is responsible for gathering information, providing technical advice, and making recommendations to the Secretary on advancing mobility access for the disabled community through automated driving systems. Recommendations are also reported to the Committee on Energy and Commerce of the House. The Disability Mobility Advisory Council, established by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, consists of members appointed by the Secretary of Transportation for three-year terms. The Council is responsible for providing technical advice and recommendations on advancing mobility access for the disabled community through automated driving systems. The Council's recommendations are reported to relevant congressional committees. The Council may request technical assistance and detail federal employees to assist in carrying out its duties. Members of the Council serve without payment and expenses. The Disability Mobility Advisory Council, established by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, consists of members appointed by the Secretary of Transportation for three-year terms. Members serve without pay, except for travel and per diem expenses for meetings called by the Secretary. The Council will terminate 6 years after the enactment of this Act. Definitions include "automated driving system" as hardware and software capable of performing dynamic driving tasks, and "dynamic driving task" as real-time operational functions for on-road traffic. The term "highly automated vehicle" refers to a motor vehicle equipped with lateral and longitudinal motion control, monitoring of the driving environment, object and event detection, response execution, maneuver planning, and enhancing conspicuity. The term "highly automated vehicle" refers to a motor vehicle equipped with an automated driving system, excluding commercial vehicles. The term "operational design domain" refers to the specific conditions under which a driving automation system is designed to function. If SAE International revises certain definitions in Recommended Practice Report J3016, they must notify the Secretary of the revision. The Secretary must publish a notice in the Federal Register to inform the public of any new definition for "highly automated vehicle" unless it is determined that the new definition does not meet motor vehicle safety needs or is inconsistent with the purposes of chapter 301 of title 49, United States Code. If the Secretary notifies SAE International that the new definition is not acceptable, the existing definition will remain in effect. The Secretary may update definitions for "highly automated vehicle" without following certain procedures if deemed necessary. The definitions for "highly automated vehicles" need to be updated due to significant changes in circumstances impacting motor vehicle safety.
